comments.body: This would allow for interesting contraptions and farms, this should be added.
We shouldn't have to ask for this. All versions should be the same. The Java edition has so many more features then bedrock its sickening. And at this rate its just going to become more and more.
This is a huge java edition feature and it would be perfect for the Parity update, I would personally rather see this than the 3D items

Iâ€™m kind of counting on this because I have a concrete powder converter designed in my bedrock edition world, and for it to be functional, I need this feature. Itâ€™s so useful in the java edition, I canâ€™t believe they left this out of bedrock.

I would love to see this in Bedrock. In my opinion this is perfect for the parity updates that Mojang is pushing out. Having some similarity in farm types can make collaboration across platforms easier and more enjoyable
Please add this so we can make concrete maker
Yes, please. It is difficult to collect sufficient resources in Bedrock to "scale up" your builds in survival. TNT contraptions would greatly help. This would be a great parity feature.
It is such an important feature on java it is so sad to have to even ask
Please bring this parity to Bedrock. I'd love to have a blasting chamber but there's no point at the moment.
That's parity change is very importantn, I'd like make farms with TNT 100% efficient

Currently, our only solution for automatically destroying blocks is a wither cage, which sadly requires bedrock to acquired in survival. Allowing 100% tnt drop rate would let us use something other than an unintended exploit to automate breaking blocks.
This would open the door to fully afkable concrete makers, cobblestone generators, tree farms, etc. on Bedrock Edition
I was expecting this for Bedrock in the recent Nether update. Please can you add it as a bug fix ASAP.
There is no real reason why this is not a feature in bedrock edition. I can see myself using this in Tree farms and cobblestone generators.
It can also help with concrete, cobble, and tree farms.
It's just disappointing how this is not in the game. Because of this, AFK tree farms are almost impossible in bedrock

The lack of this feature makes it difficult for Bedrock players to strive for large builds. Not having this feature reduces the Bedrock player's ability to gather large quantities of sand and wood and greatly slows the ability of producing large quantities of concrete in an efficient way. This is one of many reasons the Java version of the game remains the favored version. Bedrock players are penalized and stunted in making large scale projects due to issues like this.
With out this, tnt is pretty pointless in bedrock
100% TNT drop rates are an essential feature to many of coolest farms in the game. At the current drop rate TNT is essentially useless for farming.
Or maybe they could add Weaker Type of TNT or change "fireballs" form dispensers to explose after hitting blocks.
I'd just like to be able to use TNT to look for ancient debris without losing all the gold and quartz.
I would love if that would be :o
When fixed, this should NOT be hackfixed by turning down the blast radius.

As a player now of minecraft for over 6 years and most of it being on bedrock. I love the game and all is new updates but feel that small parody tweet such as this one would make the game so much more in line with what you see Content creators doing online with there builds and ideas wile also allowing older more technical players like myself new mechanics we haven't yet been able to play with on bedrock yet.
With all these new farmable blocks in the game coming recently and still no try way of gathering them other than with your standard enchanted tools, some others through trading and bartering, 100% drop rate would open the doors so to so many more colours creations.... balance, like all things should be

I can't believe this hasn't been added yet; mining with TNT would make gathering resources and creating tunnels easier and less time-consuming.
Tn

I need this

I'm surprised this isn't already added as it's a pretty big accessibility issue...
They really should add it, it's such an improvement for people who are hard of hearing or deaf, making it a thing would be so great and I consider it not being there yet an oversight
CC is genuinely one of the most useful options in Java, for those that can and cant hear. Please please add this to Bedrock

there is features not in bedrock and java

bedrock missing features: no debug menu no nether building and subtitles (i think bedrock edition is more challenging)

java missing features: no dyable water no allow deny and border blocks and no spawner in the creative inventory (again i think java is also challenging)
Yes please! I need this to detect nearby caves when mining. :3
as someone who is hard of hearing i absolutely need this

There is ABSOLUTELY NO EXCUSE for not providing visual cues or subtitle alerts as this is a major accessibility issues and from what i resesrched online, this has not been addressed/fixed for YEARS?!?!?!? ðŸ¤¬
2021 is almost over and this is still is still an issue?

its outrageous this isn't available STILL (end of 2021) !!
its really hard for me to play with others and know i can hear whats going on around me.. 
so with out this feature its really hard to not play alone ... and even then i can't always hear ...

:(

Honestly the fact that it wasn't implemented almost immediately as bedrock was rolled out is ridiculous. It's a basic accessibility function and is quite literally the bare minimum for accessible gaming nowadays.

I'm not Deaf or Hard of Hearing, but I do have sensory & processing issues. And trying to follow audio cues is pretty much impossible for me.

This needs to be implemented immediately. Especially if they want to avoid a lawsuit considering the FCC requires a certain level of accessibility with their new regulations.
I have apd and captions are a must for me!
I can't track sound directions, need this
I'm honestly shocked and disappointed that this important accessibility option for captioning is nowhere to be found.  Please, this is THE #1 most important thing to fix for so many of your players.
it would be in my opinion a good idea
This should definitely be added.
as someone with a hearing-impaired daughter, I'd like to have her playing experience on bedrock on par with the java edition.
I think this would be great too. Good for accessibility & general convenience.
I know Microsoft values accessibility, so it seems like the lack of captions in the Bedrock edition is a huge miss.

I would have thought this would have been done by now!

Accessibilty should be one of the priorities for Mojang, amongst all of the other great work they do.
I don't hear creepers, skeletons, spiders or phantoms until they've already attacked me, I really wish that bedrock edition had captions like java does.
I need this
This would be so useful it would make finding caves and dungeons easier
As a player who normally has to have the sound off, captions would be very useful so that I don't get blown up all the time.
Just wondering how many more deaf people have to die in their hardcore bedrock worlds before they finally add this feature..
Bedrock still does not have subtitles. I fail to see why such a crucial accessibility option is STILL missing from the more widely-available version of the game.
WE NEED THIS
Why doesnâ€™t this exist already? I have hearing issues and my gameplay is impaired, I canâ€™t play properly on my switch even though thereâ€™s an acCeSsiBilIty section. Please add :((
Please....

No subtitles makes bedrock virtually unplayable for me and makes me wonder why we even bother having an accessibility menu. It is very very necessary for me with hearing loss, and it sucks because it's the cross-platform edition that 'includes' everyone I want to play with otherwise.
People with hearing aid need this I am extremely surprised they didnt add it to both versions

I always play with captions on with Java, but since a lot of my friends only play bedrock, I was aghast to find out subtitles aren't already in :< PLeeeaease, I use the heck outta subtitles since I like to listen to music and am much more visual when it comes to playing games (Often muting or significantly turning down game sounds)
Tried Bedrock again today, and remembered why it's frustrating to play: hard of hearing, and can't always hear the nearby monsters. This is an accessibility issue and deserves parity.

This is not only for those who play without sound enabled but actually for people with audition disability, should be already in game to be honest as bedrock is the one aiming for cross platform gameplay.
2022 and still no dice? I have reduced hearing on one side so on Java I could use the direction indicators to place sounds, badly missing on consoles and mobile bedrock

Almost two years since this post, and Bedrock is still missing subtitles. At this point, this is more of a major accessibility issue over a simple parity issue - the Bedrock edition of the game is legitimately inaccessible to deaf or hard-of-hearing players and I'm extremely disappointed that they still have not corrected this.

Please add this! Iâ€™m a Java player and I just introduced my mom to Minecraft. She already had a Switch, so she plays on Bedrock. She keeps asking what every sound is and is scared of everything. I wanted to turn on subtitles for her so she wouldnâ€™t freak out over nothing. Then I saw that it wasnâ€™t an option on Bedrockâ€¦
Please, it should be a thing in accessibility for many reasons. This is the one thing I rely on in java just put it in bedrock.
Honestly disgusting that this still isn't a feature? Like why haven't they implemented this yet :(

I need this. I have issues with sounds, and I will sometimes use music to help drown out trigger sounds. I need this so I can play the game the same as everyone else. People who are deaf can't play the same as those who are able to hear fully. There's an accessibility barrier, and as someone with disabilities, it saddens me that Bedrock is less accessible than Java.
I actually can't believe we're still waiting for this. Inconsiderate to HoH players.

It's shocking that they haven't put it on Bedrock yet. You would think they would add such an important feature to the version on all the consoles ... I sincerely hope captions get added. Seeing other comments from people who really need them makes me frown.
I need this, I'm unable to tell where noises come from (direction wise) and I use subtitles on Java edition always.

Between people with hearing impairments, and people with auditory processing issues, this is a MAJOR accessibility issue. How is gameplay fair for them as it stands right now? Honestly it floors me that this wasn't rolled out with the original program.
With the 1.20 update having some inclusivity features, this is a perfect time to implement subtitles.
Still needing this !!!

This is a pretty glaring mistake from mojang / microsoft - this is a completely basic accessibility issue and should be addressed immediately as a no brainer - any clear reason for why this has not been implemented in all versions of the game?

This is a very basic, very common accessibility need.  Keeping the auto CC on my computer settings turned on does not help with Bedrock.  Quite frankly, this is one issue that keeps me playing Java and rarely playing Bedrock because I can't hear.  I don't know a hostile mob is near me by sound.  The only way I know when a mob is near is because they just attacked me or killed me.  I can't hear them coming.  

I can't believe this was put up as an idea 2 years ago and there is still nothing in Bedrock.
So very disappointing.

I am extremely disappointed that this is not already an option. This is a clear instance where a small change could help an entire community of deaf, hard of hearing gamers, as well as people who simply have audio processing issues.

Please add this to bedrock, I usually play with headphones in to help with me hearing monsters but there are times that this just isn't possible. This is a very helpful tool for accessibility and should be set as a priority. (I regularly use text to speech for chat messages and I find it helpful.)

This is absolutely a needed feature, I'm surprised it doesn't exist already, partly since it already exists on another version of the game. I understand that they aren't programed and whatnot the exact same way, but clearly they've done it before and can do it again. It also isn't just a convivence, I know deaf people and people hard of hearing, it's an important feature that helps them play their game. 

Also, having plenty of accessibility settings for blind and seemingly none for deaf shows a clear decided factor of what they find more important. Which I find insulting, they shouldn't pick and choose accessibility, they need to fix this ASAP.
Please, please add subtitles. I have horrible hearing and tinnitus and it would make my gameplay so much easier and engaging if I could properly differentiate the sounds.
I'm hard of hearing so this is vital for me to know what mobs are around! If I'd known Bedrock didn't have this, I don't think I would have gone with Bedrock over Java...
Yes!!! This is so important for most people!
This is a very useful accessibility feature missing for many deaf people in the world.
i heavily rely on it on Java bc I have issues with sound direction. I struggle a lot on my friends Bedrock SMP now as a result  :(

I agree! Huge issue with Minecraft bedrock
This is sorely needed please!
I need this as I have really bad auditory processing issues so sometimes I just cannot understand any sounds this game makes.
This needs to be available for accessibility. Come on, Mojang.

i'm a java-only player but this is mindboggling to me. the fact that mojang is apparently totally silent on the issue too - i've been unable to find statements of any kind. nothing that even says 'we're workin on it but struggling because of X issue, or Y platform'. just utterly leaving disabled bedrock players in the dark on this. it's 2023, and if i were at mojang i'd be embarrassed by this.

It is November 2023 and there has been ZERO communication from Microsoft on adding subtitles/CC to bedrock? This isnâ€™t a â€œwe would really love this featureâ€ it is â€œthere is a whole group of people who NEED this due to varying accessibility issuesâ€ (and many more people who would generally benefit from it existing.)

I understand Java and Bedrock are fundamentally different in function/code but subtitles/CC is a BASIC function! If low budget TV Shows/Movies/Internet Media can do itâ€¦ why canâ€™t Microsoft (especially when it is existing on Java?)??? Itâ€™s infuriating and a spit in the face to millions with a common disability/condition.

Whatâ€™s the deal Microsoft??
Not only is this a big accessibility issue, but this also is nice for players who want to see where sounds are coming from easily.
Itâ€™s been 3 years please add this. Itâ€™s not fair

Yes! Here from 2024, Iâ€™m very upset this still hasnâ€™t been implemented or even spoken on. Like others before me have said, this is a huge accessibility issue- the most basic, even. How is there text-to-speech for chat, ways to make text and buttons larger, ways to change chat font and color to be more readable, ways to change background opacity of certain UI features, yet.. no subtitles?
Unbelievable this game still doesn't have subtitles. This needs to be a much higher priority for the development team, not random new mobs like armadillos.
It's ridiculous that this option doesn't exist in Bedrock!

Please PLEASE add subtitles to Switch/Bedrock. I miss out on so much and I wish we could have the same accessibility features as Java. :(
Insane this feature doesn't exist in every iteration. Fix your house Microsoft.

why has this not been taken care of already? It's clearly an issue, and singles out disabled people specifically. I'm very disappointed Mojang clearly has no interest or urgency in fixing this obvious issue. It's significantly lowered my interest in supporting them as a business.
Need this for accessibility reasons pleaaaase, just like how they work in Java
This is a good suggestion, just add a switch to the video options.

This is a massive issue for accessibility, and for player experience and general parity. As a long time Java user who has recently started playing bedrock for other accessibility features (controller support being the biggest one) I am really disheartened to discover that the CRITICAL feature of subtitles doesn't exist in Bedrock. I'm honestly shocked, and pretty disappointed. I love this game, and want to be able to enjoy it with my friends, but without subtitles, I (and MANY others) am unable to do so. This should be top priority.
The fact that this hasn't been added to Bedrock yet is a travesty. You say you care about you customers/player base yet you continue to leave accessibility out of your game.

I have trouble with auditory processing and it's even more difficult when there's a delay between executing an action and the sound that it's supposed to make.
I've had creepers spawn in my houses before because I couldn't hear monsters in a cavern underneath.

Please no...  It's a neat feature, but it can be equally annoying in other situations.

I'm a huge redstone nut in Java edition and while there are other redstone related reasons I have not made a permanent switch to Bedrock this one has enough work arounds to make the new version a challenge but still doable.

honestly I love the bedrock edition, but when I figured out that quasi-connectivity was gone, just about everything I made before bedrock was entirely broken or had a big workaround.  I was finnaly understanding how it worked and how great of a bug it was, then one day it was all gone.  Please Mojang add this helpfull bug back into the game again.

@LateLag, did you know that creepers were born out of a coding bug? Sometimes bugs are fun and become features. I play Minecraft: Xbox One Edtion, but it isn't updated anymore and can't be bought anymore so I can't play it with friends who are new to the game unless they buy it used on disc. Minecraft: Xbox One Edition was as similar to the Java Edition as they could get it. When I play it I get a prompt regularly to switch to the bedrock edition and get reminded each time that it is not updated anymore. So because of allmost being forced to switch to the bedrock edition I want it to be like Minecraft: Xbox One Edition, so more or less like the Java Edition but optimized for a console. If on the Xbox there was a real choice like on pc where you can play both the Windows 10 and Java Edition which both get updates I wouldn't want it. It is awesome to have two flavours of your favorite game, but not if they stop serving one of them. Then you want what remains to be your favorite flavour, and for that it needs some of the weird ingredients that make it special.
Please stay on topic, thanks.

I have a thought about this. Perhaps add a redstone object called a COIL. The Coil would be made from redstone around a piece of iron. Functionally the Coil would conduct redstone into or out of it just like a piece of redstone - conducting through but not up or down in the way blocks do. Redstone on NSEW would automatically connect to it on any side. BUT

The Coil when active would then bud-power any other blocks within the bud powering range-mechanic as per standard bud powering mechanics. This meaning you could use the coil as an alternative to bud powering and remove the glitch from the game (replacing it with a mechanic)
What I suggest is you right click pistons to choose if they can be bud powered

I read that the observer was added into Bedrock instead of quasi-connectivity, but it isnâ€™t the same because BUDs in Java are sort of like a t flip-flop (The piston will stay extended until updated)while observers give off a pulse when there is any update. This feature is really important.  Since there is no universal "how to" manual for Minecraft, your only real resource for how to do certain things in the game is via wiki articles and youtube videos that are seemingly 90% Java.  I can deal with a missing feature, but when fundamental behavior is different then it becomes really difficult to trust what you see online, extremely difficult to determine what you are doing wrong, and nearly impossible to find a resource on how to "fix" the problem.

Respectfully, I disagree.

I would rather not have a behavior like this intentionally added to Bedrock edition.  There are some cool Java creations that take advantage of quasi-connectivity but not cool enough to warrant confusing my kids (or myself, for that matter) with difficult-to-predict behaviors.

To me, it seems like energy might be better spent ironing out some of the existing idiosyncrasies in the redstone implementation.  Reliable bi-directional flying machines, reliable 2-4-0 double piston timings, and sand/gravel not occasionally breaking when moved by a piston are all things I would rather see long before this is considered.

I don't envy Mojang trying to figure out how to square this circle. QC is confusing and annoying but also incredibly useful and powerful. There are some things that you can't do in Java because QC exists, and some things you can't do in Bedrock because it doesn't.

Adding QC to Bedrock would cause a lot of confusion and frustration, and break a lot of existing builds.

Removing QC from Java would cause a lot of confusion and frustration, and break a lot of existing builds.

Keeping things the way they are ALSO causes a lot of confusion and frustration, and breaks people's builds if they're building from tutorials for the wrong edition.

As an experience Bedrock redstoner, I don't want this to be implemented, for many reasons.

First off, it is a quite strange mechanic which would confuse many new players, sort of similar to Bedrock's piston randomness. 

Secondly, it would break a huge number of redstone contraptions in Bedrock Edition, and many Bedrock reasoners would be really annoyed.

Thirdly, it would make a Bedrock exclusive bug-turned-feature, redstone torches on pistons turning of if the piston turns on, almost useless as most arrangements of it in contraptions would result in a burnout clock. The unique Bedrock mechanic is really useful and can even account for some use cases where quasi-connectivity is used on Java, notably in vertical piston extenders.

Fourthly, its implementation couldn't be the exact same as in Java due to the fact that Bedrock Edition doesn't use block updates to make its redstone work, likely due to block updates being too laggy for low end devices. Either the redstone circuit system would always check extra blocks below the blocks it normally checks for components, removing quasi-connectivity's function as a block update detector and making redstone contraptions even more bulky, or pistons would be the only redstone components that block updates make check their redone state, but block updates don't progress from block to block instantly in bedrock, and pistons in bedrock extend 1 redstone tick after being powered, making it's usage even more limited.

I actaully made a similar bug report before I saw this one.

MCPE-68622

In Minecraft Bedrock edition, the Offhand is way less powerful than MC Java Edition. You can only use shields, totems, arrows, and maps. (And maybe a couple other little things). In Java Edition, you can literally put anything you want in the offhand, and activate it when your main hand is inapplicable. This is really helpful. You can keep fireworks there for easy flight access, food for easy food eating, and use pairs. Some pairs are ladder and block (to make a quick ladder tower), Pickaxe and Torch (For mining), Pickaxe and block (for building), and many other things. Sometime there are two main inventory items you need for a project, and with the Offhand, you can just use one slot, whereas in Bedrock edition, you have to switch BACK and FORTH and BACK and FORTH. The offhand tool is a very convenient quality of life change, yet it hasn't been fixed in MCPE since it came out 4 years ago! We also need a button like F to swap hands, or even keep this button in the unmapped control category. I really hope that this relatively easy code-fix is implemented into MCPE.

Regarding the comment by TakingItCasual - one way to fix this could be;

When an item enters a hopper, it enters an 'array' in C++. That array is built using 0-indexed keys and when the hopper wants to push an item, it systematically works its way down the array, remembering the last key it pushed, and then pushes the next highest key number, returning back to key 0 when there are no keys higher than the current one.

For example:
Hopper #1 - pushes key 0, then on the next push, key 1, then key 2.

As each hopper receives an item (Hopper #2), it is entered in to an 'array' for that hopper (#2), using the next available key. If hopper #2 already has an item in slot 5, then the item from Hopper #1, enters the Hopper #2 array as key 0. When hopper #2 pushes its item, it will push key 4 (slot 5) first, then key 0 (slot 1), because hopper #2 recorded that it last pushed an item from key 3 (slot 4). This way of using arrays within C++, tied to each hopper, ensures all hoppers within a chain move items in the same order they receive an item. This ensures items do not flow out of sequence when moving through hopper chains and will enable parity between the Java version and Bedrock version. If each hopper in a chain, is also triggered beginning with the last hopper, working backwards to the very first hopper, this will also ensure that several items moving through a hopper chain, continue to run in the order than they were first pushed from Hopper #1 to Hopper #2.
They do transfer things in order donâ€™t they? Or item sorters wouldnâ€™t work
However... you can make a randomiser with hoppers because of this

For a hopper chain:
A->B->C->D->Chest

If the hoppers are processed in the inverse order in the chain
D, C, B, A then there will not be any issue.

In a general case, if a directed graph is created based on how the hoppers are connected to each other, as long as there is no hopper cycle in the connections, the sequence in which the hoppers need to be updated can be easily calculated.

For cycles it might not seem trivial

A->B->C->A

but also logically there is no need for a predeterministic order in a cycle, as long as the hoppers in each cycle are processed in a fixed order of the cycle starting from any point it is fine.

The code can keep the directed graph in the memory when the corresponding chunks are loaded so the order could be preserved.

-----------------

Even if the hoppers are processed in a random order, as long as the order does not change every tick, again there will not be an issue in most cases. I imagine the code is not literarily using a random function to determine the order and most likely is using a data structure like a set that does not preserve orders when new items are added or removed, so if the data structure holding the hoppers change to something that keeps the orders stable, then this issue will not persist.

To still allow moving of cauldrons with pistons in Java, the dyed water cauldron has to be a separate block from cauldrons and water cauldrons. To allow the dyed water cauldron to be moved with a piston, it cannot be a block entity. The block states are:

  • level - Ranges from 1 - 3, used to determine water level.
  • red - Ranges from 0 - 255, used to determine red colour component in water.
  • blue - Ranges from 0 - 255, used to determine blue colour component in water.
  • green - Ranges from 0 - 255, used to determine green colour component in water.

The block has to use the RGB colour model without being a block entity.

I don't think that zero tick should be inplemented into Bedrock for a few reasons. But before that I want to address a misconception that I see in the comments before I comment.

1. A zero tick pulse is a redstone pulse that turns on and off in the same tick. An observer normally outputs a 2gt pulse.

2. A zero tick pulse should be differentiated from a 1gt(1 game tick, 2gt=0.1s) pulse and a 2gt pulse. Although it can be used to instantly move a block, the most noticeable difference (in Java) is how they interact with entities. When powering a sticky piston with a block in front, if the pulse is actually 0gt, the block won't move the entity at all. With 1gt the block will move the entity by a bit, but not so much as 2gt. 

If you want to learn more about 0-tick, I highly recommend the wiki article and videos on Youtube such as this one.

Now for the actual reasons :

1. Currently it is unclear whether the whole 0-tick thing is intended. There is a bug report about it. 

2. Farms utilizing 0-tick is unlikely to be intended.

3. If instant pistons are added like java (e.g. retracting a redstone block instantly loses its power), it will break a lot of current timing-based contraptions. What's worse than that is the performance issue. Though instant wires are cool, faster pistons will introduce more lag.

4. A lot of the 0-tick pulse generators is based on BUD, and most others are based on update orders. As BUD is unlikely to get introduced into bedrock, those based on update orders may not work at all in bedrock.

We really don't need this. Firstly, workarounds exist for block spitting. Secondly, 0-tick is not the same as block spitting. Thirdly, workarounds exist for 0-tick farms, such as making sand fall and turn back to a block in the same tick, or using water for sugarcane.

I have a few points I would like to make:
1. Zero-tick farms are a bug. However, that has nothing to do with zero-ticks themselves. I call them "tick-abuse farms" because they force a crop to try to grow by emulating a random tick (you can see this on Java Edition by setting the randomTickSpeed to a large value). For some reason, the crop mistakes the moving sand ticking the crop for a random tick and tries to grow.

2. While zero-ticks are likely a bug (in this case, an artifact of single gametick differences in update speed between 2 redstone signals, like the difference between a 1-tick repeater and a comparator), 1-ticking is a feature which I believe should be a part of Bedrock. Last I played, the piston extension speed was not even consistent. 1-tickng on its own makes redstone feel snappy and responsive, on Bedrock it just feels slow.

3. Piston block spitting is in my opinion something which Bedrock deparately needs. It vastly simplifies most contraptions, allows for flying machines, and don't really cause any problems when not used.

4. While many here clearly dislike BUDs, I honestly feel that they make redstone a much better system. They are the only way to do many things, in fact. For instance, stacked pistons can extend in sync without extended circuitry. If one is causing issues, a simple slab or piece of glass will suffice to fix it.

TL;DR: Piston block spitting, BUDs, and 1-tick pistons should be in the game. 0-tick should probably not.
